stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on programming the game's overworld. Key activities included debating and redesigning the intro and first level's gating mechanism, modeling a new 'Pachyderm' enemy, discussing the feasibility of a split-screen co-op mode, and setting up the technical framework for overworld event flags.

development_findings.summary: The project's scope has increased from a planned 185 stars to 193, with Kaze speculating it might reach 200 to achieve a round number.
development_findings.quote: We started with a hack that had planned to have like 185 stars and now we have 193. I guess we scope creep like a couple stars.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a split-screen co-op mode and believes a drop to 20 FPS would be an acceptable performance trade-off on the N64.
development_findings.quote: I think multiplayer is probably going to drop an RSP on 30 FPS level to 20 FPS. But 20 FPS on the N64, honestly, is it that bad? Ocarina of Time was 20 FPS.

development_findings.summary: A key design debate occurred regarding how to gate the first level. The initial idea of a 10-coin requirement was replaced with a narrative intro to avoid it feeling like a chore and to better encourage exploration.
development_findings.quote: I think I really, really want the player to collect 10 coins... [later] I see a point of it being somewhat of a chore. That thought does make sense to me.

development_findings.summary: The game's opening has been redesigned: Mario will arrive by boat, which is immediately destroyed by an enemy, forcing the player to start in the water and learn the swimming controls while getting a panoramic view of the island.
development_findings.quote: My idea is, we have the intro cutscene of Mario going here... a Nap-E-Nut just fucking munches your boat and Mario jumps off. And lands in the water here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze modeled a new 'Pachyderm' enemy from scratch, using a pear model as a base shape and taking inspiration from an AI-generated image for the hat, demonstrating a pragmatic and resourceful modeling process.
Kaze identified a need to create a new system for save flags for overworld events, deciding to allocate new space in the EEPROM as the current structure is insufficient for the game's needs.
Kaze encountered a bug with his 'Fast64 Redrun' tool that prevented him from adding new materials in Blender, forcing him to switch to the slower Eevee rendering engine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's development philosophy is to spend significant time improving tools and gathering knowledge before tackling a task to ensure it's done efficiently and well.
context_findings.quote: If you had six hours to cut down a tree, he would spend four hours sharpening his axe, which is maybe not the most effective mindset to have, but it is a good showcase of the mindset we go into with this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is interested in AI as a technology but dislikes the mainstream hype and commercialization, finding the discourse around it delusional. He believes its main danger is the concentration of power through automation.
context_findings.quote: It sucks that AI has become like a mainstream topic. I prefer it when it was just like a thing that nerds cared about, because now that it's a mainstream topic, like a commercial thing, people are so delusional and annoying about it.

context_findings.summary: In a discussion about the 'Tortoise and the Hare' fable, Kaze argues the tortoise was arrogant and delusional to accept the race, and winning doesn't retroactively make the initial decision wise.
context_findings.quote: I think we can all agree that playing the lottery is stupid. Doesn't mean that as soon as you win the lottery, suddenly you're a genius for having played the lottery.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed there are unspecified legal issues concerning payment for team member Biobak, but affirmed that he will be compensated.
context_findings.quote: Well, there are some legal issues right now, but don't worry, he will be paid.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about his lawnmower being repaired, which he plans to personify by adding googly eyes and treating it like a pet.
context_findings.quote: You guys will all be rejoiced to hear that I have my lawnmower back. The missing my lawnmower arc is finally over. And he is now upgraded with new wheels.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is actively considering adding split-screen co-op multiplayer, having already thought through potential technical and design solutions for performance, dialogue, and single-player-only sections.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently reworking a level to reduce its scope and make it a 'smaller mission'.
biobak.quote: Biobak is actually working on reworking this one right now. He wanted a smaller mission.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided feedback on Kaze's initial idea to gate the first level with a coin-collecting challenge, prompting Kaze to reconsider the approach.
biobak.quote: You think this is such a bad idea that we shouldn't be doing this, Biobak?

biobak.summary: Kaze mentioned there are 'legal issues' related to paying Biobak for his work, although he assured the viewers that Biobak would be paid.

zeina.summary: Zeina is currently working on an animation for a 'ball breaking scene' in the game.
zeina.quote: Zeina's working on the animation right now.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present during the stream, and Kaze acknowledged her presence when discussing the music being played.

key_stories.title: Gating the First Level
key_stories.summary: Kaze debated how to gate the first level to encourage exploration. After considering and modeling a coin-collecting obstacle, he decided it felt too much like a chore and instead designed a new narrative intro involving a shipwreck to achieve the same goal more organically.
key_stories.challenge: How to gate the entrance to the first course in a way that encourages exploration of the overworld without feeling like a chore for the player.
key_stories.process: Kaze's initial idea was a Pachyderm enemy from Yoshi's Story. He modeled it, but after feedback from Biobak and self-reflection, he worried it would be a chore. He brainstormed alternatives like TNT (rejected as not 'Mario-ish'), Bob-ombs, and boulders before landing on the intro cutscene idea.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze pivoted from a mechanical gate (a Pachyderm requiring 10 coins) to a narrative one. The new plan is an intro cutscene where Mario's boat is destroyed by a 'Nap-E-Nut', forcing him to start in the water, learn to swim, and see the entire island from afar.
key_stories.key_quote: I wanted something to block this that forces the player to go to just one random location that's like, on the outer edge of the island. And that's the goal here, to get the player to just move somewhere once, you know?

key_stories.title: The Split-Screen Co-op Question
key_stories.summary: Kaze explored the possibility of adding split-screen co-op. He weighed the technical challenges and performance costs against potential solutions for design issues like dialogue and single-player sections, leaving the feature as a viable but undecided possibility.
key_stories.challenge: Determining if split-screen co-op is a feasible addition to the game and how to solve the technical and design problems it presents.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically outlined the major hurdles for implementing co-op. He discussed performance, suggesting 20 FPS is acceptable. He considered community suggestions for handling dialogue and single-player-only events, concluding that it seems possible but would have performance implications for the single-player experience as well.
key_stories.outcome: The feature remains under consideration. Kaze has identified potential solutions for performance (widescreen rendering with black bars), dialogue (one player's screen goes fullscreen), and single-player sections (swapping players on hit), but no final decision has been made.
key_stories.key_quote: I think multiplayer is probably going to drop an RSP on 30 FPS level to 20 FPS. But 20 FPS on the N64, honestly, is it that bad? Ocarina of Time was 20 FPS.

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly stated, 'there are some legal issues right now, but don't worry, he [Biobak] will be paid.' This was mentioned in passing without further explanation.
questions: You mentioned some 'legal issues' regarding team compensation. Could you elaborate on the challenges of managing finances and payments for a global, remote team on a fan project?
How is the project structured from a financial or business perspective? Is there a formal agreement between core contributors?
What systems have you put in place to ensure everyone is compensated fairly for their work?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak is reworking a level because 'He wanted a smaller mission.' This implies a change in scope for a specific part of the game.
questions: Kaze mentioned you were reworking a level to be a 'smaller mission.' What was that level originally, and what prompted the decision to scale it back?
How do you and Kaze collaborate on level design? What does the feedback process look like when one of you feels a design's scope needs to change?

open_questions.context: Kaze noted that the planned star count has grown from 185 to 193, and might reach 200. He casually referred to it as 'a little bit of scope creep.'
questions: The star count has grown by at least 8 stars. How does the team decide when a new idea is worth adding, potentially increasing the project's scope?
Is there a point where you say 'no more new ideas,' or is the process more organic? How do you balance creative freedom with the need to actually finish the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is working on an animation for a 'ball breaking scene.'
questions: Kaze mentioned you're working on animations for the game. Can you walk us through your creative process?
What are the unique challenges of creating new animations that must fit within the technical limitations and aesthetic of the N64?
How do you and Kaze collaborate when an animation is needed for a new mechanic or enemy he's implementing?

open_questions.context: Kaze went on a tangent about a thought experiment where he would only say things that are objectively provable, concluding it's impossible and would make him seem insane.
questions: You had a fascinating thought experiment about only speaking in objective truths. How does that kind of deep, analytical thinking influence your approach to programming and the logic-based problems you solve in game development?
Does this philosophical perspective ever clash with the more creative, subjective aspects of game design?
